title: What is the fastest internet speed in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Internet speed is relative. Where do you live? Internet speeds and pricing vary greatly by geographical area. The speeds are slower and the prices are higher in remote areas because there is less competition to lower prices and there are fewer subscribers to share the costs of the equipment and service. Some remote and rural areas of the U.S. with few options would be happy to pay a premium amount for even a 1.5 Mbps DSL connection. Whereas people living in the select locations that have access to Google Fiber can enjoy relatively inexpensive 1 Gbps (1000 Mbps) Internet service.  The average broadband speed in the USA is currently around 15.6 Mbps. Measuring Broadband America - February 2013  That being said, Remember, Internet bandwidth is shared among all the devices connected to your home network's router.  Many people would likely be surprised at how many active connections their wireless router has. I have dozens. cell phones, tablets, iPods, game consoles, laptops, desktops, ROKU boxes, Internet enabled devices such as TVs and audio receivers, and the list goes on. In simple terms, the more users and devices you have, the more speed and data limits will be required.  A lot will depend on what Internet providers are available in your specific area and what levels of service they offer in that location. To compare speed and prices of your local competitors, go to a ISP comparison site that lets you input your address, and compare the pricing and terms of the offers that are available in your area. In the US you can use this one Broadband Internet in My Area otherwise do a search for "ISP comparison" at your favorite search engine.  The physical address is needed because some services, particularly DSL, are very distance sensitive. For example you might be able to get a specific level of service while your next door neighbor can't. You'll want to pick the fastest plan that fits your budget. In some areas this can be 3000 Mbps+. But these high end broadband plans are expensive. You may find that something in the 25 to 100 Mbps range might satisfy your needs at a much lower cost. Good Luck...

TOP SPEED: 255 terabits per second, or about 32 terabytes per second DETAILED REPORT 4th Place Speed: 1.4 terabits per sec, or .175 terabytes a secondYear: Jan 2014Hardware used: Commercial-grade fiber optics cablesBy: Scientists in the U.K ..... ( Those speeds would allow you to download 44 uncompressed HD films (at 4GB each) in one second, or the entire English version text of Wikipedia in .06 seconds.)NoTe: The accomplishment was a joint effort between French telecom companies Alcatel-Lucent (now owned by Nokia) and BT. They used seven different 200 gigabit-per-second connections to achieve the blistering speeds.It stands as the fastest trial using commercial equipment.3rd Place Speed: 26 terabits per secYear: may 2011Hardware used: Single fiber laserBy: Karlsruhe Institute of Technology in Germany2nd place Speed: 43 terabits of data per second (5.375 terabytes per second)Year: August 2014Hardware used: A multi-core optical fiber and laser transmitterBy: Technical University of Denmark (DTU) …... (At those speeds, you could download 1 gigabyte of data in about 0.2 milliseconds. The average blink of an eye takes somewhere between 100 and 400 milliseconds, according to data from Harvard.)NoTe: The university was one of the first to test out seven core glass thread fiber made by Japanese telecom company Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation.1st Place Speed: 255 terabits per second, or about 32 terabytes per second /Year: October 2014Hardware used: Multi-modal fiber linesBy: Researchers at the Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands and the University of Central Florida ….. (This feat would make it possible to transfer a 1GB movie in .03 milliseconds, or one terabyte of data in just .03 seconds.)NoTe: They similarly used a seven core hexagonal arrangement and were able to keep the size of the cable to just 200 microns, or about .008 inches thick. This wasn’t just a lab test either—the connection was measured on a one-kilometer stretch of fiber.But by 2011, speeds of 100 terabits-per-second had already been reached, but only using multi-laser setups..The record stood for years before new advancements in fiber completely changed the game Thank you

The fastest Internet in America is in Chatanooga, TN, and is at 10 gigabits per second. The Tennessee state government passed a law banning the sale of Internet by this consortium outside of city limits, at the request of the major ISPs who apparently don't want customers with fast Internet. (They also had the definition of broadband reduced to barely over ISDN.) Whether or not the law of Constitutional, well, currently that's not before the courts to find out. Anyways, you're just going to have to suffer the slower speed. The fastest widely-available Internet speed is to be found in South Korea, at 33.5 megabits per second, which is much slower but it's understandable that a nation has a different set of requirements than a city. I would consider this to be the real definition of broadband Internet. In Sweden, the fastest home Internet speeds run at 40 gigabits per second. This is also the fastest defined Ethernet. That is the ideal speed. Internet 2 offers speeds of up to 100 gigabits per second to major institutions. The current speed record, set in the UK, for an actual Internet connection is 1.4 terabits per second. OC-3072, the highest speed in the CCNA workbook is 19.44 gigabits per second, which is pathetic. That's two Chattanoogans playing Elite: Dangerous.

The claim is absurd by definition as the new combined carrier will have a monster amount of acquisition debt and Legere is stepping down as a CEO next year. Hence, the future of 5G in America is questionable, notwithstanding the unnecessary anti-Chinese rhetoric and tariff-prone administration. The US has lost its lead and it won’t be able to catch up even if the bands / frequencies are available. Unfortunately, Canada (America’s little sister) is bound to follow suit as their current government is “kissing” US ass. I meant that literally, not figuratively.

DID YOU KNOW? Nasa has an internet speed of 91 GB/s![1] I know exactly what you must be thinking… Why do they need such a fast connection?  just kidding, of course. The real reason they have a 91 GB/s internet connection probably has something to do with the amount of data they receive from satellites and rovers in space. Edit: As a number of you have pointed out in the comments, I seem to have misunderstood this.This speed is the LAN speed between two super computers. The maximum speed ever achieved between these two beasts was 91 GB/s. This is actually not available in internet connectivity (browsing google or facebook). The supercomputers are having this huge LAN capacity to receive and analyse data from various experiments (like the LHC!). The satellite links are not LAN. My bad. PS: Damn, this answer’s getting a lot of views and upvotes. Thanks! Footnotes[1] NASA's Internet connection is 13,000 times faster than yours

response.answer_text: It’s really not that simple of a question; the Internet doesn’t really work like that. Except for some countries, that heavily control/regulate/censor their connectivity/access : government run/controlled telecommunications providers/networks. The fastest single circuit capacity in regular use is 100Gbps (100Gig Ethernet). Between any two points, even between two networks, one can “aggregate” these links into a logical “channel” … I’ve heard of 16x 100G links, so 1.6Tbps groups. But I’m sure there are larger ones. BTW, they could all run over the same fiber pair, or not. That’s a whole other discussion (multiplexing signals). The US was first to test 100GigE in production (and I presume in the lab) - meaning genuinely connected to the Internet (within the Comcast backbone, between Philadelphia and NYC). I happened to be around that project, I believe more than 10 years ago now. There are many ways to measure this general concept of a question. There is no simple answer.

As of June 2019, a business can order dedicated Internet access or IP transit in multiples of 100 Gbps from several ISPs, such as AT&T. 2 x 100 Gbps, 5 x 100 Gbps, etc. 100 Gbps costs under USD $50,000 per month outside a data center or Internet exchange point, and considerably less in a DC or IXP. The need for heat diffusion and a lack of native switch interfaces are among the factors that have kept higher port increments, like 400 Gbps or 1 Tbps, from being offered commercially. Fibre Channel (for storage area networks) and InfiniBand (for clustered computing) offer higher throughput, but are not packetized. The QSFP+ pluggable optical transceiver standard also includes 200-Gbps options for gigabit Ethernet, but compatible switching equipment is not yet common. Quad Small Form Factor Pluggable–Double Density (QSFP-DD) modules can support 400-Gigabit Ethernet (and Internet), but as is often the case in telecom and computing, vendors often need to lobby vigorously so that their technology becomes standardized. Keep in mind that there needs to be a business case for all of this. It should be abundantly clear that a single household would not saturate a 10-Gbps connection (which incidentally is offered by several residential ISPs), much less a 100-Gbps connection. Even a large enterprise may not need more than 100 Gbps at a given site. Among ISPs peering traffic with each other, a lower port increment is generally more convenient than a higher port increment, so Nx10 Gbps remains far more common than Nx100 Gbps. 100 Gigabit Ethernet - Wikipedia

44,200,000 MB per seconds. Yea, I am here with the latest world record set in Australia recently. Researchers from Australia's Monash and RMIT universities have recorded the fastest internet data speed ever that is 44.2 Terabits per second. At that speed, approximately 1000 high definition movies can be downloaded in a fraction of second. The researchers claimed that they achieved this unbelievable speed by some sort of device, that replaces around 80 lasers found in many existing telecoms hardware, with just a single piece of equipment called the Micro Comb. Lecturer in electrical and computer systems at Monash University, Bill Crocoran said that this would probably be helpful for a wide varieties of industries, not just Netflix users, lol. Keeping in mind that how this modern world is continuously putting increasing pressure on bandwidth infrastructure, this research could be a backbone for the future of internet in the upcoming years. This can be defined as an enormous breakthrough.  (Image via Getty images) Sources : Australian researchers record world’s fastest internet speed from a single optical chip Fastest ever internet speed achieved in Australia

Everyone is mentioning commercial internet speeds, but the fastest connection full stop was achieved very recently In Australia, they achieved a transfer speed of 44 terrabits per second. To put that into perspective one full HD movie is around 2–5 gb, lets say 5 for ease so you can get 200 movies into one terabit so times that by 44 and you get 8,800 that’s not just 8,800 films though. that’s 8,800 films every single second so let’s say you were to spend a full 24 hours downloading movies, there are 86,400 seconds in a day (roughly), so 8,800 films times 86,400 seconds = 720,360,000 films per day. now according to the AFI, AMPAS and BFI (various cinematography companies) there are only around 500,000 feature length films in existence (that’s a film that is at least 40 minutes long), so with this internet connection if you had to storage and the access to all those films, you could download every single film ever made 1,440 times in one day which actually converts down to a very nice and round Every movie ever made once a minute

Within its own country, each country has the fastest Internet connection to local content. When I had an ISP, Google put in a big fat server farm to cache Youtube content. Our customers got faster access to that cached content than they would from anywhere else in the world. The same would be true for all ISP’s of a size large enough to attract a Google cache. It isn’t really meaningful to ask which country has the fastest connection, because countries have many connections to many different data sources. For example, a company in Japan might have a gigabit connection from NTT to service its local customers, while a US company might only have a share of a few hundred Mbps circuit to reach Japan. Overall, the country with the most Internet backbone bandwidth is the USA, while the country with the most Internet bandwidth per Internet user is a toss up between Singapore and Korea.

The fastest residential speed so far is 10Gbps, first rolled out in Minneapolis, but spreading to other cities.  Fastest home internet access ever rolls out in US city. The fastest transmission link used inside the internet is harder to say, since many times, multiple parallel links get "bonded" to the same destination, as in this 12-core petabyte-per-second link (New Data Cable reaches 1 Petabyte per second). Do you consider the speed of a single link (which itself may be bonded "lanes") or the aggregate of links between two identical points? Researchers have acheived speeds as high as 255 Tbps in a single fiber (255Tbps: World’s fastest network could carry all of the internet’s traffic on a single fiber | ExtremeTech), but I do not think it is in production at this time.

If you ask for right now, go check south Korea, but about future tech,,,If you ask for Band width, It possible to make a special Band width to evev TB or HB or so on. Just look around you and see how different Cables can do and how fast is your Hard drive.But if you ask for ping & Latency, the Answer is speed of light because nothing can travel faster than light, light can go 7 times around the earth in 1 sec, mean if you click a button and wait for respond considering that it’s exactly in opposite side of the earth, it take 0.0625 sec to go and same to return the respond mean your ping would be 0.125 sec and no tech according to physics laws can surpass that, Actually must Internet cables use light fibers that are the same. But if you ping is lower than that. it just mean you are closer to Host not that you Internet is Faster.Internet is going around the world, so speed is relative. you might be able to get max speed from a Host in your Local town and a Host in other continent might seem slow.

Why do you ask? It is actually a valid question. If just out of curiosity all the answers below are valid. In reality it is actually the opposite that matters. How fast is the ICP (Internet Content Provider) deliver data to you. So to put it differently, in a very few instances I will see any higher speed then 100 to 200 Mbps on my 500Mbps fiber (and I will always have above 500Mbps internet speed both up and down). The only time so far that I have peeked out was on the download of Windows 10 from Microsoft and that is after 4 years of having 500Mbps. It is like installing a really fast SSD in your computer, why should you switch to an SSD that is twice that fast, you will hardly notice in normal usage. But if you have a few really fast SSD´s that you transfer data between then it matters. But to directly answer your question. You can as a private user get 10Gbit/s in Sweden today IF you are on the right optical fiber network at a cost of 50 USD per month. I expect to be able to upgrade to 10Gbit/s before the end of 2020 but I would have to pay 60 USD per month (and a 3000USD gear upgrade to my home network…).

What country has the fastest internet connection and how did they have such? The correct answer is: none. An internet connection is made up of many, many things. Your speed is determined by the slowest link between you and where you are connecting to. For example, my internet connection to Quora goes through 18 different networks between my computer and theirs. My speed is the slowest of those networks. I am on a 100 Mbs network connection and my actual download speed right now is 116.4 Mbs. Quora is excruciatingly slow. Is my network? Nope. It’s somewhere down line. Eventually, most internet traffic hits what is loosely called the internet backbone. Depending on which piece you are using, it runs between 100 Gbs and 400 Gbs. Google has a fiber cable going under the ocean that runs at 60 Tbps. That piece isn’t in any one country. It connects the US and Europe and is one of many. So, hopefully you can see why nobody can really answer your question. Thanks for the A2A, Franz.

There isn’t really one. Are you looking for the fastest broadband speed at home? In which country? In UK most homes get either ADSL + (max 24Mbps) or Fibre to the Cabinet, (Max 72Mbps). Virgin don a 300Mbps Cable solution and BT do a 300Mbps Fibre to the Premises option. This apparently is going up to 1bps (I have 80Mbps FTTP). If you are a business, you can easily get leased lines as 1Gbps or even 10Gbps. The data centre I used to have a bunch of servers in, in 2001 has a 19Gbps connection to the internet. Its leased lines run up to 10Gbps, although these will be very expensive (100Mbps leased line is around £350 per month).

The answer depends on circumstances and time. In the 1990s, we were amazed when we first got 256 kbps; in 2006, I was delighted with 2 Mbps, and now I am unhappy with “just” 10 Mbps of my current connection. Why? Because in 2006, I wanted to download the 4 GB installation of Half-Life 2 through the 2 Mbps connection; in 2017, I want to download the 50 GB installation of DOOM (2016) through the 10 Mbps connection. So even though my connection is 5x faster, my experience is actually 2.5 times slower. I assume that in 2025, I will be unhappy with the 100–250 Mbps fiber optic cable connection and will envy the South Koreans and thei 1 Gbps fiber optic connections. And DooM (2024) will require 500 GBs, probably :-) Nevertheless, 10 Mbps is often cited as the break-off point between slow and fast internet, because it allows things like “Watching full HD streams from YouTube”.

The simplest definition of “High speed internet” is when you can successfully brag about it to your friends and family. Likewise “Low speed” is when they brag to you. Having experienced an increase in bandwidth of over a million times in my working life, the one constant thing I know is that technology speed is not constant, and peoples expectations increase as they notice others have faster tech. In Australia, “High Speed” is often regarded as 100 Mbps, as that is the fastest package that NBN offers (the incumbent near monopoly wholesaler). So my connection at 300+ Mbps (iiNet HFC) is regarded as Ultra High speed because probably less than 5% of Australians have access to an ISP with faster than 100 Mbps connection available (at home rather than commercial rates). When NBN Tier4+ becomes more widespread with its gigabit internet, that will of course change.

The answer to this question changes form year to year, since bandwidh doubles every 18 to 24 months. You can get internet connections from 25 Mbs to 300 Mbs right now. Be aware though that these are maximum speeds, not average speeds. Most DSL and cable modem connections to your home use a shared backbone to the DSlam device and so you may get blazing high speeds at off peak hours but you may see only a fraction of the max speed on peak. So, ask your provider how they populate their network and what are the average uplink and downlink speeds. Whatever the numbers are also realize that you will need to revisit this issue every 18 to 24 months as bandwidth increases.

I am going to suggest that it would be a fight between the UK and the USA. The US is one of the major contributors to the internet growth and a key market. The UK on the other hand is well developed but it is also a key hub for international connectivity. Singapore might also qualify for an honourable mention because many international fibre connections pass and they probably have the most connectivity for the smallest population. How do you measure fastest connection? Per person? The whole country? Domestic Internet connectivity? Peak or average? If we are talking about domestic internet connectivity then Akamai publishes a report called 'the state of the internet' and that says that South Korea has the highest average speed followed by Norway and Sweden. Singapore has the fastest average peak internet speed but is only 7th in average connection speeds. (As of Q1 2017) Q1 2017 - Average Global Broadband Speeds Top 7.2Mbps as UK Hits 16.9Mbps State of the Internet Report | Akamai

Do you mean residential internet to your home? or internet connection on your smartphone? or at work? Are looking which ISP has the best performance ? Verizon , ATT, and Google offer residential gigabit to the home, but it isn’t available eveywhere. Typically the “best “ residential ISP is going to vary from location to location. So it’s going to depend on where you live. Same for mobile smartphone access- it depends on location. 5G is getting a lot of hype and potentially offers higher speeds than 4G , but a general rule of radio is that the higher the frequency- the higher the bandwidth - but the shorter the range. Internet at work also varies a lot. - Depends on where you work Universities and academia on the research side of things tend to have gigabit or higher . Large data centers often have multiple 10 Gb/s and 40 Gb/s connections. There are a few places with 100 Gb/s or 1000 Gb/s connections as well.

I think you mean what’s the greatest bandwidth connection? (Bandwidth is capacity, not speed) If you mean speed, it would be a latency of just above 0 ms (in other words, a near instantaneous response) If you mean bandwidth, from a domestic subscriber perspective it’s around 1 Gigabit per second, for business customers 10 Gig is available in many places, and in well served areas 40 or 100 Gig. If theory you could create a connection at much higher rates but few businesses need it. There’s a popular misconception that bandwidth = speed and that somehow a Gigabit connection is ‘faster’ that a 100 Megabit connection. It isn’t, it just has a higher capacity. If you’re using < 100 Megabits both will perform identically all other factors being equal.

This usually has been South Korea as a country (The Fastest Internet Speeds In The World - Forbes) but the latest figures from Akamai in 2013 seem to indicate Hongkong (Hong Kong takes Internet speed title) and reports have mentioned that Google's fiber in Kansas & Missouri are the fastest anywhere (Google Fiber) this is assuming you are looking for fastest internet speeds when you say maximum. Some of the limitations are physical like right of way and there are often regulatory hurdles too. The economics of providing such high capacity is also a constraint!

To answer that question you need to define how you measure that. Remember, all the internet is networks all communicating with each other. If I have the fastest internet line in the world and I am browsing a slow website then the speed I have is the same as the slow website. But it will probably be a datacenter that will have the fastest in the world currently.But recently the so called world record is 44.2 terabits per second from Australian researchers.

Lol - this is not an answerable question. The “Internet” does not exist as a “thing.” It is not possible for it to be fast or slow. The connection from your ISP may be rated fast or slow — usually by that ISP, themselves. For example, today your access to a website might be “Fast” from ISP A, and “Slow” from ISP B. However, tomorrow, it might be completely the opposite.

It is completely subjective and the definition of a “High Speed Internet” might vary from person to person. For a person who has used a dial up connection his entire life will call a 512kbps connection a “High Speed Internet.” If that same person uses the 512kbps connection for the next 6 months and is given a taste of a 2Mbps connection, the definition of “High Speed Internet” will change from 512kbps internet connection to a 2Mbps internet connection. For me, I am used to a 30Mbps connection, and I will call it a “Very High Speed Internet” connection but as human tendencies go, one is simply not satisfied with what he has xD So I always wish for an even higher internet speed. If given an opportunity I’ll be the first one to grab it. Anything higher than my current 30Mbps plan.

I believe the current (2016) definitions of High speed, rather than basic / narrowband are: US > 25 Mbps (broadband)UK > 24 Mbps (superfast)Korea > 10 Mbps (high-speed)Essentially High-Speed must allow the streaming of a 1080p movie, see: How much bandwidth is required to stream 1080p?  Basic Broadband: UK >= 2Mbps (Broadband Delivery UK)

NASA's Internet connection is 13,000 times faster than yours. 91 gigabits per second. The space organization's shadow network can transfer 91 gigabits per second, or 91,000 megabits per second. For comparison, the average broadband connection speed in the U.S. is 6.6 megabits per second - or more than 13,000 times slower.

“What is the fastest possible internet connection that you can get?” Are you asking as a private individual user? Or Are you wanting know the ultimate fastest, money is no object connection? As an individual user the fastest depends on where you live and who the providers are. For a “money no object” connection; we are probably talking millions of dollars to contract with a Tier 1 Internet Provider for a connection that would probably saturate a 10Gb network connection.

The fastest single link allegedly in production is currently 400Gb/s. Arista Introduces 400 Gigabit Platforms Juniper's 400GbE Engineering Prowess on Display at Verizon Cisco Makes Terabit Scale Ethernet Networking a Reality with 400 GbE Technology

Note that all of these cited “rankings” are AVERAGES - in many cases a country will have a wide range of speeds depending on where you are IN the country and sometimes on which ISP you choose from. For example, the USA still has a lot of areas that only have Dialup Phone or Sat for internet options (and a few spots can’t even get THAT much due to worn-out phone lines and no line-of-site TO the sats) - but other areas offer GIGABIT to the desktop (either fiber, or fiber-backbone with a Gigabit Ethernet “final link” setup). Large countries are always going to have a hard time competing on “average” speed, due to the large rural “very spread out” areas that it’s not AFFORDABLE for anyone to build out fiber TO in order to make fast speeds available.

The internet isn’t organised along national lines so this question doesn’t really make sense. There are some fast backbones owned by some providers and there are some slow ones owned by others. And speed isn’t everything…

There is an ISP in Chattanooga, TN that has a 10gbps home internet connection service. That is not a typo: 10 gigabits per second to the home. At the time I first read about it, 12–18 months ago, they had one customer for that service: a medical imaging specialist who works from home. I believe they were the first in the US to have an actual customer, though they weren't the first to have the service available.
